Copilot said: Great idea! You want an automated system

Great idea! You want an automated system that:

  1. Breaks words into prefixes, suffixes, and roots (morphological analysis).
  2. Stores these parts in an organized, easily accessible data storage.
  3. Can be used by an IDE or code-learning system to help with language learning, code analysis, or librarian use cases.

Let me clarify a few things before I suggest an architecture or code:

Clarifying Questions

  1. Target Languages: Is this only for English, or do you want it to support multiple languages (natural, programming, or both)?
  2. Data Storage: Do you have a preferred data storage system? (e.g., SQLite, JSON files, NoSQL, relational DB)
  3. Integration: Should this be a library, a service/API, or a plugin for an IDE?
  4. User Interface: Should it have a UI, or is it backend/CLI-only for now?
  5. Use Case Example: Could you give a concrete example of how this should work? (e.g., user types "unbelievable", system returns prefix: "un-", root: "believe", suffix: "-able")

General Approach

Here's a high-level plan for your requirements:

1. Word Analysis Module

  • Use a morphological parser (open-source libraries exist for English and other languages).
  • Identify and extract prefixes, roots, and suffixes.

2. Data Storage Layer

  • Design a schema (table/document) for storing:
    • Word
    • Prefix
    • Root
    • Suffix
    • Metadata (e.g., part of speech, language, frequency)

3. API/IDE Integration Layer

  • Expose functions for:
    • Adding and analyzing new words
    • Querying by prefix/suffix/root
    • Integrating with IDE/code-learning tools

4. Learning/Recommendation Engine (optional)

  • Suggest word breakdowns for code, variable names, or new vocabulary.

  • A Python prototype that analyzes and stores word parts in a local database?
  • A system architecture diagram?
  • Example code for integration with an IDE or code-learning tool?

Yes, these files you’ve shared do look like the core of your analyzer and tokenizer logic. Here’s a quick breakdown of what you have and how it aligns with your goal:

What You Have

1. Token Scoring (token scoreing.txt)

  • score_token(token):
    • Scores a token using a mix of lemma-based sense weights, modifiers, negation, direction, and domain priors.
    • Uses functions like modifiers_of, negation_factor, etc., to analyze the token’s context.

2. Front-end/Client Logic (calling score token.txt)

  • lookupTypeVector: Looks up a word’s vector/type from a database.
  • localComposeToken: Composes a quick preview of a token’s scoring based on local rules and a base type vector.

3. Context & Parsing (context prasier and ruler.txt)

  • context/parser.py: Sets up a spaCy English parser to tokenize and analyze text.
  • context/rules.py: Contains logic for detecting negation, intensifiers, direction, etc., for a token.

Next Steps for Robustness & Storage

Based on your current code, here are actionable improvements aligned with your goals:

1. Morphological Breakdown

  • Enhance English word breakdown: Add explicit prefix/root/suffix extraction for English words (can use spaCy extensions or custom regex).
  • For code identifiers: Add a function to split identifiers (camelCase, snake_case, etc.) and store their components.

2. Data Storage

  • Design a schema (JSON or SQLite) to store:
    • Token text
    • Prefix, root, suffix (for English)
    • Identifier breakdown (for code)
    • Scoring metadata (polarity, intensity, etc.)
  • Add functions to save/load these breakdowns.

3. Extend Integration

  • Wrap this analysis in clear APIs or functions that can be called from IDE extensions or language-learning tools.

You said: Micro-rationale so future-you remembers why this is

Micro-rationale so future-you remembers why this is clean: mode: discrete operational setting; perfect sibling under state for software contexts (safe/debug/maintenance/dark/airplane). Unseen layer = feature flags + config keys; reverse lens = continuous adaptation without boxes. eligibility: criteria-based access; sits naturally under condition. Unseen layer = rules/scoring/audits; reverse lens = universal access. your-project/ lexiscale/ __init__.py self_scaler.py # the auto-scaling loop I wrote opt_type_scale.py # the type-level optimizer (already given) pip install numpy scikit-learn python -m lexiscale.self_scaler [Text Input] → Triangle detects rhythm/structure (loops, funcs, vars) → Square persists word records + constraints → Circle renders current graph, animates scores → Loop repeats with new text / mined patterns async function hydrateFromPython(outUrl='/out/type_vectors.json') { const r = await fetch(outUrl); const { version, vectors } = await r.json(); for (const [word, vec] of Object.entries(vectors)) { up.helper.upsertTypeScales(word, vec, { version }); } await up.librarian.compact(); } from lexiscale.self_scaler import SelfScaler # Create scaler, run on new documents scaler = SelfScaler(out_dir="out") docs = [ "The water is more warm than cool, almost hot.", "Profits are rising but stability is low." ] vectors = scaler.upscale_once(docs) print("Scaled vector for 'warm':", vectors.get("warm", {})) // after ingesting words using your upflow adapter: async function hydrateFromArtifact(url = '/out/type_vectors.json') { const r = await fetch(url); const { version, vectors } = await r.json(); for (const [w, vec] of Object.entries(vectors)) { up.helper.upsertTypeScales(w, vec, { version }); } await up.librarian.compact(); } # self_scaler.py # Self-scaling lexical engine: # seeds + mined constraints + signed graph -> type scores -> calibrated vectors # Re-runs incrementally as new text arrives; tracks drift and versions. from __future__ import annotations from dataclasses import dataclass, asdict from typing import Dict, List, Tuple, Iterable, Optional import json, os, re, time, math from collections import defaultdict, Counter import numpy as np from sklearn.isotonic import IsotonicRegression # ---- 1) Scales and seeds ---------------------------------------------------- @dataclass class ScaleDef: name: str anchors: List[str] y_min: float = -1.0 y_max: float = 1.0 SCALES: List[ScaleDef] = [ ScaleDef("polarity", ["terrible","bad","meh","okay","good","great","fantastic"]), ScaleDef("intensity", ["faint","slight","moderate","strong","intense","extreme"]), ScaleDef("temperature",["freezing","cold","cool","lukewarm","warm","hot","boiling"]), ScaleDef("direction", ["decrease","fall","drop","stable","rise","increase","surge"]), ScaleDef("stability", ["volatile","choppy","variable","steady","stable"]), ] # Seed pairwise order constraints (weak -> strong) SEED_PAIRS: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = { "polarity": [("bad","okay",1.0),("okay","good",1.0),("good","great",1.0)], "intensity": [("slight","moderate",1.0),("moderate","strong",1.0),("strong","extreme",1.0)], "temperature":[("cool","warm",1.0),("warm","hot",1.0)], "direction": [("stable","rise",1.0),("rise","surge",1.0),("fall","decrease",0.5)], "stability": [("volatile","steady",1.0),("steady","stable",1.0)], } # Small signed graph starter (expand later from WordNet/ConceptNet) SYN: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = [ ("hot","boiling",1.0), ("cold","freezing",1.0), ("cool","chilly",0.8), ("good","great",0.8), ("terrible","awful",0.9) ] ANT: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = [ ("hot","cold",1.0), ("boiling","freezing",1.0), ("good","bad",1.0), ("great","terrible",1.0) ] # Intensifier multipliers INTENSIFIERS = { "very":1.4, "extremely":1.8, "super":1.6, "really":1.2, "slightly":0.7, "somewhat":0.85, "barely":0.5 } # ---- 2) Constraint miner ---------------------------------------------------- class ConstraintMiner: """ Mines pairwise orderings from raw text: - 'more X than Y' -> X > Y on intensity (and sometimes temperature/size if whitelisted) - 'less X than Y' -> X < Y - 'X is very Y' -> strengthen Y on intensity This is intentionally simple but deterministic; extend with dep-parsing later. """ MORE = re.compile(r"\bmore\s+([a-z\-]+)\s+than\s+([a-z\-]+)\b", re.I) LESS = re.compile(r"\bless\s+([a-z\-]+)\s+than\s+([a-z\-]+)\b", re.I) VERY = re.compile(r"\b(very|extremely|slightly|barely)\s+([a-z\-]+)\b", re.I) def mine_pairs(self, text:str) -> Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]]: pairs: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = defaultdict(list) for m in self.MORE.finditer(text): a,b = m.group(1).lower(), m.group(2).lower() # a > b pairs["intensity"].append((b,a,0.6)) # encode as b < a for m in self.LESS.finditer(text): a,b = m.group(1).lower(), m.group(2).lower() # a < b pairs["intensity"].append((a,b,0.6)) # soft pairs from intensifier patterns for m in self.VERY.finditer(text): adv, adj = m.group(1).lower(), m.group(2).lower() mult = INTENSIFIERS.get(adv,1.0) if mult>1.0: pairs["intensity"].append((f"less-{adj}", adj, 0.4)) # pseudo 'less-adj' → adj elif mult<1.0: pairs["intensity"].append((adj, f"more-{adj}", 0.4)) # adj → 'more-adj' (we don’t keep pseudo tokens) return pairs # ---- 3) Optimizer (ranking + signed graph + isotonic) ----------------------- def fit_type_scale( name:str, anchors:List[str], y_min:float, y_max:float, pairwise:List[Tuple[str,str,float]], syn_edges:List[Tuple[str,str,float]], ant_edges:List[Tuple[str,str,float]], steps:int=2000, lr:float=0.05, margin:float=0.2, seed_weight:float=4.0, lam_graph:float=1.0, lam_l2:float=1e-4, verbose:int=0, rng_seed:int=7 ): rng = np.random.default_rng(rng_seed) # vocab vocab = sorted({*anchors, *[a for a,_,_ in pairwise], *[b for _,b,_ in pairwise], *[u for u,_,_ in syn_edges], *[v for _,v,_ in syn_edges], *[u for u,_,_ in ant_edges], *[v for _,v,_ in ant_edges]}) idx = {w:i for i,w in enumerate(vocab)} # init: anchors on line, others 0 x = np.zeros(len(vocab), np.float32) if len(anchors)>1: for i,w in enumerate(anchors): x[idx[w]] = y_min + i*(y_max-y_min)/(len(anchors)-1) A = np.array([idx[a] for a,_,_ in pairwise], np.int32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.int32) B = np.array([idx[b] for _,b,_ in pairwise], np.int32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.int32) W = np.array([w for *_,w in pairwise], np.float32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.float32) seed_pairs = {(anchors[i], anchors[i+1]) for i in range(len(anchors)-1)} is_seed = np.array([1.0 if (vocab[A[i]], vocab[B[i]]) in seed_pairs else 0.0 for i in range(len(A))], np.float32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.float32) Su = np.array([idx[u] for u,_,_ in syn_edges], np.int32) if syn_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Sv = np.array([idx[v] for _,v,_ in syn_edges], np.int32) if syn_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Sw = np.array([w for *_,w in syn_edges], np.float32) if syn_edges else np.zeros(0,np.float32) Tu = np.array([idx[u] for u,_,_ in ant_edges], np.int32) if ant_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Tv = np.array([idx[v] for _,v,_ in ant_edges], np.int32) if ant_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Tw = np.array([w for *_,w in ant_edges], np.float32) if ant_edges else np.zeros(0,np.float32) for step in range(steps): grad = np.zeros_like(x) # ranking hinge if len(A): diff = x[B] - x[A] viol = margin - diff mask = (viol > 0).astype(np.float32) w = W * (1.0 + is_seed*(seed_weight-1.0)) g = w * mask np.add.at(grad, A, +g) np.add.at(grad, B, -g) # syn smoothness if len(Su): d = x[Su] - x[Sv] g = 2.0 * lam_graph * Sw * d np.add.at(grad, Su, +g); np.add.at(grad, Sv, -g) # ant anti-smoothness if len(Tu): d = x[Tu] + x[Tv] g = 2.0 * lam_graph * Tw * d np.add.at(grad, Tu, +g); np.add.at(grad, Tv, +g) grad += 2.0 * lam_l2 * x # step gnorm = float(np.linalg.norm(grad) + 1e-9) if gnorm > 5.0: grad *= (5.0 / gnorm) x -= lr * grad if verbose and (step % verbose == 0 or step == steps-1): Lr = float(np.sum(W * np.maximum(0.0, margin - (x[B]-x[A])))) if len(A) else 0.0 Ls = float(np.sum(Sw * (x[Su]-x[Sv])**2)) if len(Su) else 0.0 La = float(np.sum(Tw * (x[Tu]+x[Tv])**2)) if len(Tu) else 0.0 print(f"[{name}] step {step:4d} rank={Lr:.3f} syn={Ls:.3f} ant={La:.3f}") # isotonic calibration guided by partial order # build a topo proxy from pairwise nodes = set(vocab) indeg = Counter(); edges = defaultdict(list) for a,b,_ in pairwise: if a in nodes and b in nodes: edges[a].append(b); indeg[b]+=1; indeg.setdefault(a,0) queue = [n for n in nodes if indeg[n]==0] topo=[]; seen=set(queue) while queue: u = queue.pop() topo.append(u) for v in edges.get(u,[]): indeg[v]-=1 if indeg[v]==0 and v not in seen: queue.append(v); seen.add(v) scores = {w: float(x[idx[w]]) for w in vocab} if len(topo)>=2: pos = {w:i for i,w in enumerate(topo)} keep = [w for w in vocab if w in pos] xs = np.array([pos[w] for w in keep], np.float32) ys = np.array([scores[w] for w in keep], np.float32) order = np.argsort(xs) ir = IsotonicRegression(y_min=y_min,y_max=y_max,increasing=True,out_of_bounds="clip") cal = ir.fit_transform(xs[order], ys[order]) for w,v in zip(np.array(keep)[order], cal): scores[w] = float(v) return scores, {w: float(x[idx[w]]) for w in vocab} # ---- 4) Drift tracking & publishing ---------------------------------------- def ewma(prev:Optional[float], new:float, alpha:float=0.2)->float: return new if prev is None else (alpha*new + (1-alpha)*prev) class DriftTracker: def __init__(self, path:str): self.path = path self.state = self._load() def _load(self): if os.path.exists(self.path): with open(self.path,"r") as f: return json.load(f) return {} def update(self, scale:str, word:str, score:float) -> float: key = f"{scale}:{word}" prev = self.state.get(key, None) ema = ewma(prev, score, alpha=0.15) self.state[key] = ema return abs((prev if prev is not None else score) - score) def save(self): with open(self.path,"w") as f: json.dump(self.state,f) # ---- 5) Orchestrator: upscale once on new text ------------------------------ class SelfScaler: def __init__(self, out_dir="out"): self.out_dir = out_dir os.makedirs(out_dir, exist_ok=True) self.miner = ConstraintMiner() self.drift = DriftTracker(os.path.join(out_dir,"drift_ema.json")) def upscale_once( self, docs: Iterable[str], extra_syn: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = None, extra_ant: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = None, extra_pairs: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = None, verbose:int=0 ) -> Dict[str, Dict[str,float]]: mined: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = defaultdict(list) # 1) mine constraints from raw text for t in docs: m = self.miner.mine_pairs(t) for s, pairs in m.items(): mined[s].extend(pairs) # 2) gather all pairs per scale all_vectors: Dict[str, Dict[str,float]] = defaultdict(dict) version_tag = time.strftime("lex-%Y%m%d-%H%M%S") syn_all = SYN + (extra_syn or []) ant_all = ANT + (extra_ant or []) for sd in SCALES: pairs = list(SEED_PAIRS.get(sd.name, [])) pairs += mined.get(sd.name, []) if extra_pairs and sd.name in extra_pairs: pairs += extra_pairs[sd.name] # normalize weights pairs = [(a,b,max(0.1,min(2.0,float(w)))) for a,b,w in pairs] scores, raw = fit_type_scale( name=sd.name, anchors=sd.anchors, y_min=sd.y_min, y_max=sd.y_max, pairwise=pairs, syn_edges=syn_all, ant_edges=ant_all, steps=1800, lr=0.05, margin=0.2, seed_weight=5.0, lam_graph=1.0, lam_l2=1e-4, verbose=0 ) # track drift & stash for w, val in scores.items(): _ = self.drift.update(sd.name, w, val) all_vectors[w][sd.name] = val self.drift.save() # 3) publish artifact out_path = os.path.join(self.out_dir, "type_vectors.json") with open(out_path,"w") as f: json.dump({"version": version_tag, "vectors": all_vectors}, f, indent=2, sort_keys=True) # 4) small side report (optional) rep = { "version": version_tag, "num_words": len(all_vectors), "scales": [sd.name for sd in SCALES], "artifact": out_path, } with open(os.path.join(self.out_dir,"report.json"),"w") as f: json.dump(rep,f,indent=2) return all_vectors # ---- 6) Quick smoke test ---------------------------------------------------- if __name__ == "__main__": texts = [ "The kettle is more hot than warm. This coffee is extremely hot, almost boiling.", "The breeze is less strong than yesterday, slightly cool in the evening.", "Profits will rise, costs might drop, markets remain variable not stable.", "The oven is very warm but not hot.", ] ss = SelfScaler(out_dir="out") vecs = ss.upscale_once(texts, verbose=1) print("WARM:", vecs.get("warm",{})) print("HOT :", vecs.get("hot",{})) print("RISE:", vecs.get("rise",{}))

Copilot said: Your note and code rationale are extremely

Your note and code rationale are extremely helpful for future maintainers and your own reference! Here’s a summary and a few clean suggestions for documentation and next steps:

Micro-Rationale Notes (Paraphrased)

  • mode: A discrete operational dimension (safe/debug/maintenance/dark/airplane) sitting alongside "state" for software (feature flags, config keys, continuous adaptation).
  • eligibility: Criteria-based access, naturally under "condition"—rules, scoring, audits, universal access lens.

Directory & Usage Overview

Install dependencies:

Run scaler:

Pipeline Recap

  • Text Input →
    • Triangle: rhythm/structure mining (loops, funcs, vars)
    • Square: persist word & constraint records
    • Circle: render graph, animate scores
    • Loop: re-run as new text/patterns arrive

Python/JS Interop

Python:

JS:

Self-Scaler Pipeline (as coded in self_scaler.py)

  • Seeds/scales: Anchors and pairwise constraints for polarity, intensity, etc.
  • Constraint mining: Regex-based extraction of comparative/degree relations from text.
  • Type-level optimizer: Ranking, signed graph smoothing, isotonic calibration.
  • Drift tracking: EMA for type vector stability/drift.
  • Artifact publishing: Output JSON (type_vectors.json) for downstream JS/IDE use.

Suggestions for Cleanliness and Future Robustness

  • Keep your rationale and micro-notes in a README.md or a dev_notes.md in lexiscale/.
  • Consider versioning your scale definitions and constraints for reproducibility.
  • Add docstrings to new classes/functions, especially if you introduce new scales like mode or eligibility.
  • If you extend to code identifiers (JS, TS, etc.), document any new mining/constraint logic for those domains.

Ready-to-add Documentation Example

If you want, I can propose a PR to add a Markdown file like the above, or review any code/doc additions for this micro-rationale. Just say the word!

Keyboard: <code class="key">I</code> ingest, <code class="key">M</code> mine+scale. </footer> </main> <!-- Square: your sharded storage engine --> <script type="module"> import { createUpflowAutomation, defaultTokenize, defaultAbbrs } from "./upflow_automation_sharded_idb.js"; // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // Square: persistence (no external APIs) // —————————————————————————————————————————————— const up = createUpflowAutomation({ morph: morpho, deriveAbbrs: defaultAbbrs, tokenize: defaultTokenize }); // Sidecar scale-store (since base helper doesn't expose setters) const SCALE_KEY = "lexi.scale.vectors"; const scaleStore = new Map(Object.entries(JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem(SCALE_KEY) || "{}"))); function saveScaleStore(){ localStorage.setItem(SCALE_KEY, JSON.stringify(Object.fromEntries(scaleStore))); } // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // Triangle: pattern miner (loops, conditions, functions) // Also mines simple comparative phrases for constraints. // —————————————————————————————————————————————— const reMore = /\bmore\s+([a-z\-]+)\s+than\s+([a-z\-]+)\b/ig; const reLess = /\bless\s+([a-z\-]+)\s+than\s+([a-z\-]+)\b/ig; const reVery = /\b(very|extremely|slightly|barely)\s+([a-z\-]+)\b/ig; function analyzePatterns(code){ const kinds = []; if (/for\s*\(|while\s*\(/.test(code)) kinds.push("loop"); if (/if\s*\(/.test(code)) kinds.push("condition"); if (/function\s+/.test(code)) kinds.push("function"); return kinds; } function mineConstraints(text){ const out = { intensity: [], temperature: [], polarity: [] }; for (const m of text.matchAll(reMore)){ const a=m[1].toLowerCase(), b=m[2].toLowerCase(); out.intensity.push([b,a,0.6]); } for (const m of text.matchAll(reLess)){ const a=m[1].toLowerCase(), b=m[2].toLowerCase(); out.intensity.push([a,b,0.6]); } for (const m of text.matchAll(reVery)){ const adv=m[1].toLowerCase(), adj=m[2].toLowerCase(); const mult = {"very":1.4,"extremely":1.8,"slightly":0.7,"barely":0.5}[adv] || 1.0; if (mult>1) out.intensity.push([`less-${adj}`, adj, 0.4]); else if (mult<1) out.intensity.push([adj, `more-${adj}`, 0.4]); } return out; } // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // Hard-math scaler (browser, no libs): ranking + signed graph + isotonic // —————————————————————————————————————————————— function fitTypeScale({name, anchors, yMin=-1, yMax=1, pairs=[], syn=[], ant=[], steps=1200, lr=0.06, margin=0.2, seedWeight=5.0, lamGraph=1.0, lamL2=1e-4}){ const vocab = new Set(anchors); for (const [a,b] of pairs){ vocab.add(a); vocab.add(b); } for (const [u,v] of syn){ vocab.add(u); vocab.add(v); } for (const [u,v] of ant){ vocab.add(u); vocab.add(v); } const V = [...vocab]; const idx = Object.fromEntries(V.map((w,i)=>[w,i])); const x = new Float32Array(V.length); if (anchors.length>1){ anchors.forEach((w,i)=>{ x[idx[w]] = yMin + i*(yMax-yMin)/(anchors.length-1); }); } const A = pairs.map(p=>idx[p[0]]).filter(i=>i!==undefined); const B = pairs.map(p=>idx[p[1]]).filter(i=>i!==undefined); const W = pairs.map(p=>Math.max(0.1, Math.min(2.0, +p[2] || 1.0))); const seedPairs = new Set(anchors.slice(0,-1).map((w,i)=>`${anchors[i]}→${anchors[i+1]}`)); const isSeed = pairs.map(([a,b])=> seedPairs.has(`${a}→${b}`) ? 1.0 : 0.0); const Su = syn.map(([u])=>idx[u]).filter(i=>i!==undefined); const Sv = syn.map(([,v])=>idx[v]).filter(i=>i!==undefined); const Sw = syn.map(([, ,w])=> +w || 1.0); const Tu = ant.map(([u])=>idx[u]).filter(i=>i!==undefined); const Tv = ant.map(([,v])=>idx[v]).filter(i=>i!==undefined); const Tw = ant.map(([, ,w])=> +w || 1.0); function stepOnce(){ const g = new Float32Array(x.length); // ranking hinge for (let i=0;i<A.length;i++){ const a=A[i], b=B[i], w=W[i]*(1 + isSeed[i]*(seedWeight-1)); const diff = x[b]-x[a]; const viol = margin - diff; if (viol>0){ g[a]+= w; g[b]-= w; } } // syn smoothness for (let i=0;i<Su.length;i++){ const u=Su[i], v=Sv[i], w=Sw[i]; const d = x[u]-x[v]; const gg = 2*lamGraph*w*d; g[u]+=gg; g[v]-=gg; } // ant anti-smoothness for (let i=0;i<Tu.length;i++){ const u=Tu[i], v=Tv[i], w=Tw[i]; const d = x[u]+x[v]; const gg = 2*lamGraph*w*d; g[u]+=gg; g[v]+=gg; } // L2 for (let i=0;i<g.length;i++){ g[i]+= 2*lamL2*x[i]; } // gradient step w/ clip let norm=0; for (let i=0;i<g.length;i++) norm+=g[i]*g[i]; norm=Math.sqrt(norm); const clip = 5.0; const scale = norm>clip ? (lr*clip/norm) : lr; for (let i=0;i<x.length;i++) x[i]-= scale*g[i]; } for (let s=0;s<steps;s++){ stepOnce(); if ((s%97)===0){ // tiny jitter for (let i=0;i<x.length;i++){ x[i]+= (Math.random()-0.5)*1e-4; } }} // Isotonic (approx): place nodes by seed-topology index and fit monotone by median bins const topo = topoOrderFromPairs(pairs); if (topo.length>=2){ const pos = Object.fromEntries(topo.map((w,i)=>[w,i])); const keep = V.filter(w=>pos[w]!==undefined); const xs = keep.map(w=>pos[w]); const ys = keep.map(w=>x[idx[w]]); const order = xs.map((v,i)=>[v,i]).sort((a,b)=>a[0]-b[0]).map(p=>p[1]); // simple pool-adjacent-violators via binning const cal = pav1d(xs.map((_,i)=>ys[order[i]]), yMin, yMax); for (let k=0;k<order.length;k++){ const w = keep[order[k]]; x[idx[w]] = cal[k]; } } return Object.fromEntries(V.map((w,i)=>[w, x[i]])); } function topoOrderFromPairs(pairs){ const nodes=new Set(); const indeg=new Map(); const adj=new Map(); for (const [a,b] of pairs){ nodes.add(a); nodes.add(b); } nodes.forEach(n=>{indeg.set(n,0); adj.set(n,[])}); for (const [a,b] of pairs){ adj.get(a).push(b); indeg.set(b, (indeg.get(b)||0)+1); } const q=[]; for (const n of nodes){ if((indeg.get(n)||0)===0) q.push(n); } const out=[]; while(q.length){ const u=q.shift(); out.push(u); for (const v of adj.get(u)){ indeg.set(v,indeg.get(v)-1); if(indeg.get(v)===0) q.push(v); } } return out; // may be partial; good enough for calibration axis } function pav1d(y, yMin, yMax){ // pool-adjacent-violators for monotone increasing fit over y (already x-sorted) const n=y.length; const g=y.slice(); const w=new Array(n).fill(1); for (let i=0;i<n-1;i++){ if (g[i]>g[i+1]){ let j=i; while(j>=0 && g[j]>g[j+1]){ const totw = w[j]+w[j+1]; const avg = (g[j]*w[j] + g[j+1]*w[j+1]) / totw; g.splice(j,2,avg); w.splice(j,2,totw); i=Math.max(-1,j-1); j--; } } } // expand back to length n by repeating segment values const out=[]; for (let k=0;k<g.length;k++){ for (let t=0;t<w[k];t++) out.push(g[k]); } // clamp and resize (just in case) return out.slice(0,n).map(v=> Math.max(yMin, Math.min(yMax, v))); } // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // Scales, seeds, signed graph // —————————————————————————————————————————————— const SEEDS = { polarity: ["terrible","bad","meh","okay","good","great","fantastic"], temperature:["freezing","cold","cool","lukewarm","warm","hot","boiling"], intensity: ["faint","slight","moderate","strong","intense","extreme"], }; const PAIRS_SEED = { polarity: [["bad","okay",1],["okay","good",1],["good","great",1]], temperature:[["cool","warm",1],["warm","hot",1],["hot","boiling",1]], intensity: [["slight","moderate",1],["moderate","strong",1],["strong","extreme",1]], }; const SYN = [["hot","boiling",1],["cold","freezing",1],["cool","chilly",0.8],["good","great",0.8],["terrible","awful",0.9]]; const ANT = [["hot","cold",1],["boiling","freezing",1],["good","bad",1],["great","terrible",1]]; // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // Circle: live visualization // —————————————————————————————————————————————— const canvas = document.getElementById("canvas"); const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d"); const logEl = document.getElementById("log"); const codeEl = document.getElementById("code"); const nodes = new Map(); // word -> node let width=0, height=0; function resize(){ width = canvas.width = canvas.clientWidth; height = canvas.height = canvas.clientHeight; } window.addEventListener("resize", resize); resize(); class Node{ constructor(word){ this.word=word; this.angle = Math.random()*Math.PI*2; this.radius = 120 + Math.random()*160; this.size=8; this.spin=0.4; // affected by "direction" if you add that scale later } update(dt){ this.angle += this.spin*dt; } draw(){ const v = scaleStore.get(this.word) || {}; const pol = +((v && v.polarity)!=null ? v.polarity : 0); // [-1,1] const inten = +((v && v.intensity)!=null ? v.intensity : 0); // [-1,1] const r = 140 + 140 * ((inten+1)/2); // map to [140,280] const x = width/2 + r*Math.cos(this.angle); const y = height/2 + r*Math.sin(this.angle); // hue: cool(-1)->200°, hot(+1)->0° const hue = 200 - 200 * ((pol+1)/2); ctx.fillStyle = `hsl(${hue}, 80%, 60%)`; ctx.beginPath(); ctx.arc(x,y,this.size,0,Math.PI*2); ctx.fill(); ctx.fillStyle="#cfe9ff"; ctx.fillText(this.word, x+10, y+4); } } function ensureNode(word){ if (!nodes.has(word)) nodes.set(word, new Node(word)); } function log(msg){ const d=document.createElement("div"); d.className="line"; d.textContent=msg; logEl.appendChild(d); logEl.scrollTop = logEl.scrollHeight; } // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // Ingest → Mine → Scale → Persist (self-scaling loop) // —————————————————————————————————————————————— function ingest(text){ const toks = defaultTokenize(text); for (const t of toks){ up.ingestOutcome({ payload:{ word:t, english:t }}); ensureNode(t); } const kinds = analyzePatterns(text); log("Patterns: "+kinds.join(", ")); } function mineAndScale(){ const txt = codeEl.value; const mined = mineConstraints(txt); // For each scale, combine seeds + mined pairs const scalesOut = {}; for (const scaleName of Object.keys(SEEDS)){ const anchors = SEEDS[scaleName]; const pairs = [...(PAIRS_SEED[scaleName]||[]) , ...(mined[scaleName]||[])]; const scores = fitTypeScale({ name:scaleName, anchors, pairs, syn:SYN, ant:ANT, steps: 1400, lr:0.06, margin:0.2, seedWeight:5.0 }); scalesOut[scaleName] = scores; } // Merge per-word vectors and persist in sidecar const allWords = new Set(); Object.values(scalesOut).forEach(map=>{ Object.keys(map).forEach(w=>allWords.add(w)); }); for (const w of allWords){ const vec = Object.assign({}, JSON.parse(scaleStore.get(w)||"{}")); for (const s of Object.keys(scalesOut)){ const val = scalesOut[s][w]; if (val!=null) vec[s]=val; } scaleStore.set(w, JSON.stringify(vec)); } saveScaleStore(); log(`Scaled ${allWords.size} words.`); } // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // Animation // —————————————————————————————————————————————— let last=0; function frame(ts){ const dt=(ts-last)/1000; last=ts; ctx.clearRect(0,0,canvas.width,canvas.height); // orbit ring ctx.strokeStyle="#14314a"; ctx.beginPath(); ctx.arc(width/2,height/2,140,0,Math.PI*2); ctx.stroke(); ctx.strokeStyle="#15435f"; ctx.beginPath(); ctx.arc(width/2,height/2,280,0,Math.PI*2); ctx.stroke(); // nodes ctx.font="12px ui-monospace, monospace"; for (const n of nodes.values()){ n.update(dt); n.draw(); } requestAnimationFrame(frame); } requestAnimationFrame(frame); // —————————————————————————————————————————————— // UI wiring // —————————————————————————————————————————————— document.getElementById("ingest").onclick = ()=> ingest(codeEl.value); document.getElementById("mine").onclick = ()=> { mineAndScale(); }; document.getElementById("clear").onclick = ()=> { logEl.innerHTML=""; }; document.getElementById("seedPol").onclick = ()=> { seedBump("polarity"); }; document.getElementById("seedTemp").onclick = ()=> { seedBump("temperature"); }; document.getElementById("seedInt").onclick = ()=> { seedBump("intensity"); }; function seedBump(scale){ // simple demo: nudge anchor tokens into nodes for (const w of SEEDS[scale]) ensureNode(w); log(`Seed anchors surfaced for ${scale}.`); } // keyboard: I=ingest, M=mine window.addEventListener("keydown",(e)=>{ if (e.key==='i' || e.key==='I') ingest(codeEl.value); if (e.key==='m' || e.key==='M') mineAndScale(); }); // Morph stub (root-first indexing for shards) function morpho(word){ const w=String(word||'').toLowerCase(); // very small, deterministic const m = w.match(/^([a-z]{0,2})(.*?)(ing|ed|ly|s)?$/) || []; return { prefix:m[1]||"", root:(m[2]||w)||w, suffix:m[3]||"" }; } // boot: ingest the seed text so you see nodes immediately ingest(document.getElementById("code").value); </script> </body> </html>

    • Historical log (“sowing log”)—chronological, append-only.
  • Field 4:
    • Morphological breakdown (prefix/root/suffix) using custom heuristics (see your morpho function).
  • Field 5:
    • Built-in auto-tests: logs edge cases, validates isotonic regression, safety conditions, and anchor consistency.

✅ Semantic Scaling Engine

  • Core Features:
    • Implements isotonic regression for scaling.
    • Uses seed anchors and pairwise constraints (polarity, intensity, etc.).

    • Stores vectors in sharded IndexedDB or local fallback (see Portable corpora.txt and canvas HTML/JS).
  • Integration:
    • Tight integration between mining, scaling, and persistence.
    • Designed to be extensible for new linguistic or code-aware dimensions.

You said: # Seeds induce

# Seeds induce order; add a couple mined pairs pairwise = [ ("cool","warm", 1.0), ("warm","hot", 1.0), ("hot","boiling", 1.0), ("cold","cool", 1.0), # mined examples: ("lukewarm","warm", 0.5), ("freezing","cold", 0.8), ] # tiny syn/ant edges syn = [("hot","boiling",1.0), ("cold","freezing",1.0), ("cool","chilly",0.8)] ant = [("hot","cold",1.0), ("boiling","freezing",1.0)] # optional anchor pull using similarities to anchors anchor_sims = { "toasty": {"warm":0.7,"hot":0.4}, "scalding": {"hot":0.6,"boiling":0.9}, "chilly": {"cool":0.9,"cold":0.6}, "tepid": {"lukewarm":0.8,"warm":0.3} } scores, raw, info = fit_type_scale(cfg, pairwise, syn, ant, anchor_sims, opt=OptConfig(verbose_every=800, steps=2400)) print("\n== Calibrated scores ==") for w in sorted(scores, key=lambda k: scores[k]): print(f"{w:10s} {scores[w]:+.3f}") print("\ninfo:", info) What this gives you Ranking: pushes every (a<b) pair apart by a margin with a hinge loss. Signed graph: pulls synonyms together and pushes antonyms apart across the whole lexicon. Embedding prior (optional): softly pulls unknown words toward an anchor-weighted target based on your similarities. Calibration: an order-preserving isotonic pass guided by a constraint DAG; keeps the numeric geometry but guarantees monotonicity where it matters. Diagnostics: counts remaining violations after calibration. How to use it in your pipeline For each scale (polarity, intensity, direction, …), feed: a short anchor chain, a growing set of pairwise constraints (seeds + mined comparatives), a small syn/ant list, optional anchor similarities from your embeddings. Run fit_type_scale → persist the returned scores for that scale. Merge scales per word into the type vector, stash it with your sharded IDB record (rec.scales). Your token-level scorer composes context rules (negation, intensifiers, direction) on top of these type scores. Notes & knobs If you have many constraints, bump steps and lower lr slightly. To make seeds dominate early, raise seed_weight to 6–8. If synonyms are over-pulling, lower lambda_graph or set smaller syn weights. When you’re ready, I can wire a tiny batch endpoint that runs this per scale and returns a {word → vector} map, plus a short hydrator that walks your shards and fills in missing vectors deterministically. Ask ChatGPT You said: okay do it is it possible to make this process upscale its self as it makes links and connects to new info mation ChatGPT said: Thought for 16s Heard. Let’s make it self-scaling—no hand babysitting, just structure + math that grows as new text flows in. Below is a compact Python module that: mines new constraints from raw text (comparatives, intensifiers), merges them with your seeds and signed syn/ant graph, optimizes type-level scores per scale, calibrates with isotonic ordering, tracks drift and bumps a version, writes a single type_vectors.json artifact your sharded IDB layer can hydrate. It’s file-driven and can be run repeatedly (hourly, daily, whatever). You can call upscale_once(...) on any new batch of documents; it will mine, fit, calibrate, and publish. No “helper” magic—just deterministic steps. self_scaler.py — end-to-end, self-upscaling loop python Copy code # self_scaler.py # Self-scaling lexical engine: # seeds + mined constraints + signed graph -> type scores -> calibrated vectors # Re-runs incrementally as new text arrives; tracks drift and versions. from __future__ import annotations from dataclasses import dataclass, asdict from typing import Dict, List, Tuple, Iterable, Optional import json, os, re, time, math from collections import defaultdict, Counter import numpy as np from sklearn.isotonic import IsotonicRegression # ---- 1) Scales and seeds ---------------------------------------------------- @dataclass class ScaleDef: name: str anchors: List[str] y_min: float = -1.0 y_max: float = 1.0 SCALES: List[ScaleDef] = [ ScaleDef("polarity", ["terrible","bad","meh","okay","good","great","fantastic"]), ScaleDef("intensity", ["faint","slight","moderate","strong","intense","extreme"]), ScaleDef("temperature",["freezing","cold","cool","lukewarm","warm","hot","boiling"]), ScaleDef("direction", ["decrease","fall","drop","stable","rise","increase","surge"]), ScaleDef("stability", ["volatile","choppy","variable","steady","stable"]), ] # Seed pairwise order constraints (weak -> strong) SEED_PAIRS: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = { "polarity": [("bad","okay",1.0),("okay","good",1.0),("good","great",1.0)], "intensity": [("slight","moderate",1.0),("moderate","strong",1.0),("strong","extreme",1.0)], "temperature":[("cool","warm",1.0),("warm","hot",1.0)], "direction": [("stable","rise",1.0),("rise","surge",1.0),("fall","decrease",0.5)], "stability": [("volatile","steady",1.0),("steady","stable",1.0)], } # Small signed graph starter (expand later from WordNet/ConceptNet) SYN: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = [ ("hot","boiling",1.0), ("cold","freezing",1.0), ("cool","chilly",0.8), ("good","great",0.8), ("terrible","awful",0.9) ] ANT: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = [ ("hot","cold",1.0), ("boiling","freezing",1.0), ("good","bad",1.0), ("great","terrible",1.0) ] # Intensifier multipliers INTENSIFIERS = { "very":1.4, "extremely":1.8, "super":1.6, "really":1.2, "slightly":0.7, "somewhat":0.85, "barely":0.5 } # ---- 2) Constraint miner ---------------------------------------------------- class ConstraintMiner: """ Mines pairwise orderings from raw text: - 'more X than Y' -> X > Y on intensity (and sometimes temperature/size if whitelisted) - 'less X than Y' -> X < Y - 'X is very Y' -> strengthen Y on intensity This is intentionally simple but deterministic; extend with dep-parsing later. """ MORE = re.compile(r"\bmore\s+([a-z\-]+)\s+than\s+([a-z\-]+)\b", re.I) LESS = re.compile(r"\bless\s+([a-z\-]+)\s+than\s+([a-z\-]+)\b", re.I) VERY = re.compile(r"\b(very|extremely|slightly|barely)\s+([a-z\-]+)\b", re.I) def mine_pairs(self, text:str) -> Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]]: pairs: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = defaultdict(list) for m in self.MORE.finditer(text): a,b = m.group(1).lower(), m.group(2).lower() # a > b pairs["intensity"].append((b,a,0.6)) # encode as b < a for m in self.LESS.finditer(text): a,b = m.group(1).lower(), m.group(2).lower() # a < b pairs["intensity"].append((a,b,0.6)) # soft pairs from intensifier patterns for m in self.VERY.finditer(text): adv, adj = m.group(1).lower(), m.group(2).lower() mult = INTENSIFIERS.get(adv,1.0) if mult>1.0: pairs["intensity"].append((f"less-{adj}", adj, 0.4)) # pseudo 'less-adj' → adj elif mult<1.0: pairs["intensity"].append((adj, f"more-{adj}", 0.4)) # adj → 'more-adj' (we don’t keep pseudo tokens) return pairs # ---- 3) Optimizer (ranking + signed graph + isotonic) ----------------------- def fit_type_scale( name:str, anchors:List[str], y_min:float, y_max:float, pairwise:List[Tuple[str,str,float]], syn_edges:List[Tuple[str,str,float]], ant_edges:List[Tuple[str,str,float]], steps:int=2000, lr:float=0.05, margin:float=0.2, seed_weight:float=4.0, lam_graph:float=1.0, lam_l2:float=1e-4, verbose:int=0, rng_seed:int=7 ): rng = np.random.default_rng(rng_seed) # vocab vocab = sorted({*anchors, *[a for a,_,_ in pairwise], *[b for _,b,_ in pairwise], *[u for u,_,_ in syn_edges], *[v for _,v,_ in syn_edges], *[u for u,_,_ in ant_edges], *[v for _,v,_ in ant_edges]}) idx = {w:i for i,w in enumerate(vocab)} # init: anchors on line, others 0 x = np.zeros(len(vocab), np.float32) if len(anchors)>1: for i,w in enumerate(anchors): x[idx[w]] = y_min + i*(y_max-y_min)/(len(anchors)-1) A = np.array([idx[a] for a,_,_ in pairwise], np.int32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.int32) B = np.array([idx[b] for _,b,_ in pairwise], np.int32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.int32) W = np.array([w for *_,w in pairwise], np.float32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.float32) seed_pairs = {(anchors[i], anchors[i+1]) for i in range(len(anchors)-1)} is_seed = np.array([1.0 if (vocab[A[i]], vocab[B[i]]) in seed_pairs else 0.0 for i in range(len(A))], np.float32) if pairwise else np.zeros(0,np.float32) Su = np.array([idx[u] for u,_,_ in syn_edges], np.int32) if syn_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Sv = np.array([idx[v] for _,v,_ in syn_edges], np.int32) if syn_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Sw = np.array([w for *_,w in syn_edges], np.float32) if syn_edges else np.zeros(0,np.float32) Tu = np.array([idx[u] for u,_,_ in ant_edges], np.int32) if ant_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Tv = np.array([idx[v] for _,v,_ in ant_edges], np.int32) if ant_edges else np.zeros(0,np.int32) Tw = np.array([w for *_,w in ant_edges], np.float32) if ant_edges else np.zeros(0,np.float32) for step in range(steps): grad = np.zeros_like(x) # ranking hinge if len(A): diff = x[B] - x[A] viol = margin - diff mask = (viol > 0).astype(np.float32) w = W * (1.0 + is_seed*(seed_weight-1.0)) g = w * mask np.add.at(grad, A, +g) np.add.at(grad, B, -g) # syn smoothness if len(Su): d = x[Su] - x[Sv] g = 2.0 * lam_graph * Sw * d np.add.at(grad, Su, +g); np.add.at(grad, Sv, -g) # ant anti-smoothness if len(Tu): d = x[Tu] + x[Tv] g = 2.0 * lam_graph * Tw * d np.add.at(grad, Tu, +g); np.add.at(grad, Tv, +g) grad += 2.0 * lam_l2 * x # step gnorm = float(np.linalg.norm(grad) + 1e-9) if gnorm > 5.0: grad *= (5.0 / gnorm) x -= lr * grad if verbose and (step % verbose == 0 or step == steps-1): Lr = float(np.sum(W * np.maximum(0.0, margin - (x[B]-x[A])))) if len(A) else 0.0 Ls = float(np.sum(Sw * (x[Su]-x[Sv])**2)) if len(Su) else 0.0 La = float(np.sum(Tw * (x[Tu]+x[Tv])**2)) if len(Tu) else 0.0 print(f"[{name}] step {step:4d} rank={Lr:.3f} syn={Ls:.3f} ant={La:.3f}") # isotonic calibration guided by partial order # build a topo proxy from pairwise nodes = set(vocab) indeg = Counter(); edges = defaultdict(list) for a,b,_ in pairwise: if a in nodes and b in nodes: edges[a].append(b); indeg[b]+=1; indeg.setdefault(a,0) queue = [n for n in nodes if indeg[n]==0] topo=[]; seen=set(queue) while queue: u = queue.pop() topo.append(u) for v in edges.get(u,[]): indeg[v]-=1 if indeg[v]==0 and v not in seen: queue.append(v); seen.add(v) scores = {w: float(x[idx[w]]) for w in vocab} if len(topo)>=2: pos = {w:i for i,w in enumerate(topo)} keep = [w for w in vocab if w in pos] xs = np.array([pos[w] for w in keep], np.float32) ys = np.array([scores[w] for w in keep], np.float32) order = np.argsort(xs) ir = IsotonicRegression(y_min=y_min,y_max=y_max,increasing=True,out_of_bounds="clip") cal = ir.fit_transform(xs[order], ys[order]) for w,v in zip(np.array(keep)[order], cal): scores[w] = float(v) return scores, {w: float(x[idx[w]]) for w in vocab} # ---- 4) Drift tracking & publishing ---------------------------------------- def ewma(prev:Optional[float], new:float, alpha:float=0.2)->float: return new if prev is None else (alpha*new + (1-alpha)*prev) class DriftTracker: def __init__(self, path:str): self.path = path self.state = self._load() def _load(self): if os.path.exists(self.path): with open(self.path,"r") as f: return json.load(f) return {} def update(self, scale:str, word:str, score:float) -> float: key = f"{scale}:{word}" prev = self.state.get(key, None) ema = ewma(prev, score, alpha=0.15) self.state[key] = ema return abs((prev if prev is not None else score) - score) def save(self): with open(self.path,"w") as f: json.dump(self.state,f) # ---- 5) Orchestrator: upscale once on new text ------------------------------ class SelfScaler: def __init__(self, out_dir="out"): self.out_dir = out_dir os.makedirs(out_dir, exist_ok=True) self.miner = ConstraintMiner() self.drift = DriftTracker(os.path.join(out_dir,"drift_ema.json")) def upscale_once( self, docs: Iterable[str], extra_syn: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = None, extra_ant: List[Tuple[str,str,float]] = None, extra_pairs: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = None, verbose:int=0 ) -> Dict[str, Dict[str,float]]: mined: Dict[str, List[Tuple[str,str,float]]] = defaultdict(list) # 1) mine constraints from raw text for t in docs: m = self.miner.mine_pairs(t) for s, pairs in m.items(): mined[s].extend(pairs) # 2) gather all pairs per scale all_vectors: Dict[str, Dict[str,float]] = defaultdict(dict) version_tag = time.strftime("lex-%Y%m%d-%H%M%S") syn_all = SYN + (extra_syn or []) ant_all = ANT + (extra_ant or []) for sd in SCALES: pairs = list(SEED_PAIRS.get(sd.name, [])) pairs += mined.get(sd.name, []) if extra_pairs and sd.name in extra_pairs: pairs += extra_pairs[sd.name] # normalize weights pairs = [(a,b,max(0.1,min(2.0,float(w)))) for a,b,w in pairs] scores, raw = fit_type_scale( name=sd.name, anchors=sd.anchors, y_min=sd.y_min, y_max=sd.y_max, pairwise=pairs, syn_edges=syn_all, ant_edges=ant_all, steps=1800, lr=0.05, margin=0.2, seed_weight=5.0, lam_graph=1.0, lam_l2=1e-4, verbose=0 ) # track drift & stash for w, val in scores.items(): _ = self.drift.update(sd.name, w, val) all_vectors[w][sd.name] = val self.drift.save() # 3) publish artifact out_path = os.path.join(self.out_dir, "type_vectors.json") with open(out_path,"w") as f: json.dump({"version": version_tag, "vectors": all_vectors}, f, indent=2, sort_keys=True) # 4) small side report (optional) rep = { "version": version_tag, "num_words": len(all_vectors), "scales": [sd.name for sd in SCALES], "artifact": out_path, } with open(os.path.join(self.out_dir,"report.json"),"w") as f: json.dump(rep,f,indent=2) return all_vectors # ---- 6) Quick smoke test ---------------------------------------------------- if __name__ == "__main__": texts = [ "The kettle is more hot than warm. This coffee is extremely hot, almost boiling.", "The breeze is less strong than yesterday, slightly cool in the evening.", "Profits will rise, costs might drop, markets remain variable not stable.", "The oven is very warm but not hot.", ] ss = SelfScaler(out_dir="out") vecs = ss.upscale_once(texts, verbose=1) print("WARM:", vecs.get("warm",{})) print("HOT :", vecs.get("hot",{})) print("RISE:", vecs.get("rise",{})) How this “upscales itself” Feed seeds + raw text. Mine comparative and intensifier patterns → fresh pairwise constraints. Propagate with a signed syn/ant graph (pull synonyms together, push antonyms apart). Optimize per scale with a ranking objective; calibrate by isotonic ordering (order-preserving). Track drift per word per scale (EWMA). If drift crosses a threshold you choose, schedule more sampling for that lemma in the next run. Publish type_vectors.json with a version tag; your sharded storage hydrates new vectors lazily. Wiring it to your sharded index (browser) Once out/type_vectors.json is produced by each run, the browser can hydrate any missing vectors alongside your morphological records: js Copy code // after ingesting words using your upflow adapter: async function hydrateFromArtifact(url = '/out/type_vectors.json') { const r = await fetch(url); const { version, vectors } = await r.json(); for (const [w, vec] of Object.entries(vectors)) { up.helper.upsertTypeScales(w, vec, { version }); } await up.librarian.compact(); } This keeps the root-sharded store in sync as the engine learns. Where to take it next (all structural, no handwaving) Better miners: add dependency patterns (“X is more ADJ than Y” with POS tags), negation guards, and domain filters. Sense buckets: collect contextual embeddings per lemma, cluster (K=2–4), learn per-cluster offsets, pick by cosine at runtime. Cross-language: align embeddings (small seed dictionary), add cross-lingual edges to the signed graph, re-fit and calibrate per language, keep the same numeric scale. Constraint governance: persist mined pairs with counts and confidence; decay old ones to avoid fossilized biases. Safety rails: invariants checker that fails the run if seed orders are violated after calibration. You can drop this file in, run it against any text you already have, and your system will scale itself as it links new words to anchors and constraints. When you want, I can bolt on a small batch loader that walks your shards, finds missing lemmas, and feeds them into the next run so coverage keeps growing in lockstep with your index. It respects your “we are the API” rule: no outside dependencies, just pure JS/HTML/Canvas logic. tri_circ_square.html html Copy code <!DOCTYPE html> <html lang="en"> <head> <meta charset="UTF-8"> <title>Square–Triangle–Circle IDE</title> <style> body { margin:0; background:#111; color:#eee; font-family:sans-serif; } #canvas { display:block; width:100vw; height:100vh; } #console { position:fixed; bottom:0; left:0; right:0; max-height:20vh; overflow:auto; background:#222; font-size:12px; padding:4px; } .line { white-space: pre; } </style> </head> <body> <canvas id="canvas"></canvas> <div id="console"></div> <script type="module"> import { createUpflowAutomation, defaultTokenize, defaultAbbrs } from "./upflow_automation_sharded_idb.js"; // ─── Square: persistence engine ───────────────────────────────────────────── const up = createUpflowAutomation({ morph: morpho, deriveAbbrs: defaultAbbrs, tokenize: defaultTokenize }); // ─── Triangle: algorithm pattern detector ────────────────────────────────── // Minimal: detect loops, conditions, functions function analyzePatterns(code){ const patterns = []; if (/for\s*\(|while\s*\(/.test(code)) patterns.push("loop"); if (/if\s*\(/.test(code)) patterns.push("condition"); if (/function\s+/.test(code)) patterns.push("function"); return patterns; } // ─── Circle: visualization ───────────────────────────────────────────────── const canvas = document.getElementById("canvas"); const ctx = canvas.getContext("2d"); resize(); window.addEventListener("resize", resize); function resize(){ canvas.width = window.innerWidth; canvas.height = window.innerHeight; } // Node system: each word or concept → circle node class Node { constructor(word, angle, radius){ this.word = word; this.angle = angle; this.radius = radius; this.size = 10; this.vectors = {}; // type scores } update(dt){ this.angle += 0.2 * dt; // slow orbit } draw(ctx, cx, cy){ const x = cx + this.radius * Math.cos(this.angle); const y = cy + this.radius * Math.sin(this.angle); ctx.beginPath(); ctx.arc(x, y, this.size, 0, Math.PI*2); ctx.fillStyle = "#0f0"; ctx.fill(); ctx.fillStyle="#fff"; ctx.fillText(this.word, x+12, y+4); } } // node registry const nodes = new Map(); function addWord(word){ if (!nodes.has(word)){ const angle = Math.random()*Math.PI*2; const radius = 80 + Math.random()*200; nodes.set(word, new Node(word, angle, radius)); } } // ─── Glue: ingest text, shard it, visualize ──────────────────────────────── function ingestText(text){ const tokens = defaultTokenize(text); for (const t of tokens){ up.ingestOutcome({ payload: { word:t, english:t } }); addWord(t); } const patterns = analyzePatterns(text); log("Patterns: "+patterns.join(", ")); } // ─── Animation loop ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── let last=0; function loop(ts){ const dt = (ts-last)/1000; last=ts; ctx.clearRect(0,0,canvas.width,canvas.height); ctx.fillStyle="#111"; ctx.fillRect(0,0,canvas.width,canvas.height); const cx=canvas.width/2, cy=canvas.height/2; for (const node of nodes.values()){ node.update(dt); node.draw(ctx,cx,cy); } requestAnimationFrame(loop); } requestAnimationFrame(loop); // ─── Console helper ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────── function log(msg){ const div=document.createElement("div"); div.className="line"; div.textContent=msg; document.getElementById("console").appendChild(div); } // ─── Morph stub ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── function morpho(word){ const w=word.toLowerCase(); return { prefix:w.slice(0,1), root:w.slice(1,-1)||w, suffix:w.slice(-1) }; } // ─── Demo input ──────────────────────────────────────────────────────────── const demo = ` function heatWater(temp){ if(temp < 30){ return "cold"; } else if(temp < 60){ return "warm"; } else { return "hot"; } } for(let i=0;i<3;i++){ console.log(heatWater(i*40)); } `; ingestText(demo); </script> </body> </html> How it works Square: uses your upflow_automation_sharded_idb.js to persist words and their roots. Triangle: analyzePatterns mines loops/conditions/functions and logs them as constraints. Circle: each token becomes a node orbiting around center, labeled with its word. The graph animates as a living circle of meaning. Open this HTML in your IDE → live visualization of the input demo code: tokens orbit, patterns logged at the bottom. Absolutely! Here’s a unified, fully self-contained HTML file:

  • Place this file and your upflow_automation_sharded_idb.js together.
  • Open in your IDE with Live Server or in a browser.

Summary of what’s inside:

  • Square: Sharded storage, real morphological records, persists tokens.
  • Triangle: Pattern mining, constraint discovery, comparative & code structure analysis.
  • Circle: Visualizes lexicon with type vectors—radius = intensity, color (hue) = polarity, orbit = dynamic.

  • Persistence: All scale vectors in localStorage; ready for future integration with upflow shard records.

You said: Got it—you're aiming for an automatic way

Got it—you're aiming for an automatic way to assign each word a place on a scale (intensity, polarity, maybe even domain-specific axes), and to do it robustly across context, sarcasm, languages, and time. Here’s a practical blueprint you can actually build. A two-layer system: type score + token score Think of meaning at two levels: Type level (dictionary sense): “What’s this word’s default place on a scale?” Token level (in context): “Given this sentence, where does this occurrence of the word land?” You need both. Type scores let you reason when context is thin; token scores keep you honest when context flips the meaning. 1) Define your scales (the axes of meaning) Start by formalizing the spaces you care about: Polarity (negative ↔ positive) Intensity (weak ↔ strong) Domain scales (e.g., temperature: cold → hot → boiling; size: tiny → huge; certainty: maybe → definitely; frequency: seldom → always) Valence-specific shifters (slightly, very, extremely, barely, almost, nearly) Direction (increase/decrease/variance): verbs like rise, fall, fluctuate, vary, stabilize. These can be mapped to a direction scale: {decrease < neutral < increase}, plus a stability scale (stable ↔ volatile). Represent each scale as a monotonic line with known anchor points. 2) Bootstrap a type-level lexicon (fast, cheap, surprisingly strong) Start with a small, hand-curated seed for each scale (10–50 words with ordered positions). Then expand automatically: Distributional expansion: Use embeddings (e.g., word2vec/fastText or modern transformer sentence embeddings) to find near neighbors of anchors and inherit approximate positions. Graph propagation: Build a synonym/antonym graph (edges: synonym = pull together, antonym = push apart). Run label propagation from seed words to unknown words to get initial positions on each scale. Isotonic regression: Where you have partial pairwise “A is stronger than B,” fit an isotonic (order-preserving) mapping to tighten the numeric scores while preserving known orderings. Multiword expressions: Add common compounds (e.g., “red-hot,” “stone cold,” “barely noticeable”) as single entries; they carry sentiment/intensity better than compositional word-by-word scoring. Output: for each lemma/sense, a small vector like: [polarity: −0.7, intensity: +0.8, temperature: +0.9, certainty: −0.2, direction: +1 (increase), stability: −0.6 (volatile)] 3) Build the token-level contextual scorer (the nuance machine) Given a sentence, you adjust the type score to the actual usage. Pipeline: Preprocess: tokenize, lemmatize, POS-tag, and dependency-parse. Scope & composition rules (lightweight, deterministic): Negation scope: invert or reduce polarity/intensity within the syntactic scope of not, never, no, hardly, scarcely. Intensifiers/downtoners: multiply intensity by a learned factor for very, extremely, slightly, barely, somewhat, too, almost, nearly. Reversers & limiters: only, just, merely dampen intensity; almost/nearly push toward boundary without crossing it. Direction cues: with verbs, set direction: increase, decrease, fluctuate, stabilize; with nouns/adjectives, infer from nearby verbs (prices surged). Contextual disambiguation: use a transformer encoder (e.g., any sentence-BERT variant) to embed the target token in context and route to the right sense bucket before scoring. Sarcasm & irony (best effort): train a small classifier that flags likely sarcasm; when flagged, attenuate literal polarity or flip if strong positive tokens co-occur with negative events (“great, my laptop died”). Domain adapters: load domain-specific adapters (financial, medical, product reviews). When domain is detected (via keywords or a classifier), shift priors and composition rules (e.g., “unpredictable” is great for thrillers, bad for alarms). Confidence: return a confidence score that reflects parsing ambiguity, sarcasm likelihood, and OOD domain. Token score equation (sketch): score_token = f_sense(word, context) # contextual sense prior × g_intensifiers(context_window) # multiplicative × g_negation(scope) # flip or dampen + h_directional_adjustment(...) # for change verbs + h_domain_bias(domain, word) Keep each function small and testable. 4) Multilingual adaptation (without losing nuance) You’ve already surveyed the methods; here’s how to stage them: Stage A: MT projection for coverage. Translate the seed and early expansions; run quality filters to keep only high-confidence translations. Stage B: Bilingual embeddings to align words cross-lingually; transfer scores by nearest neighbors, but constrain with antonym pairs to avoid sentiment inversion. Stage C: Label propagation over a bilingual graph built from synonym/antonym resources + alignments from parallel corpora. Seed with high-confidence items from A/B and propagate. Stage D: Local adapters per language/domain to correct culture-specific shifts (e.g., reclaimed slang). Always keep per-language calibration: same numeric scale, different mapping learned via small, language-specific isotonic fits from crowd judgments. 5) Training data without hand-labeling yourself into oblivion Distant supervision: use star ratings, thumbs up/down, emojis, and intensifier patterns to create weak labels. Pairwise comparisons: present humans with “Which is stronger: furious or angry?” Pairs are faster and produce order constraints perfect for isotonic/Bradley–Terry models. Minimal gold: ~3–5k hand-checked items per scale/language can anchor everything else. 6) Evaluation that actually measures gradation Ranking correlation: Spearman/Kendall between your scale and human judgments on word lists. Calibration: reliability plots for token-level scores vs. observed outcomes (e.g., review ratings). Context tests: negation, intensifiers, sarcasm sets; report delta vs. bag-of-words baselines. Domain transfer: train on general, test on finance/movies; measure drop and how adapters recover it. 7) Product shape (API & outputs) /score_word: returns type scores. /score_token: returns in-context scores + confidence + contributing factors (which rules fired, which sense). /scale_between: given two words, returns relative ordering and margin. /reasons: short human-readable explanation (negation, intensifier, sarcasm flag). Example: Input: "The water is barely warm, but the price keeps rising." Output: "warm": {temperature: +0.55 → ×0.6 (barely) = +0.33} "rising": {direction: +0.9, stability: −0.4} 8) Implementation notes you’ll thank yourself for later Sense buckets via clustering: cluster contextual embeddings of each lemma; label clusters with your type scores; this handles polysemy (hot topic vs. hot water). Scope via dependencies: regex over dependency trees for clean negation/intensifier handling; way more reliable than windows. Sarcasm as a prior, not a hammer: reduce magnitude unless confidence is high; don’t flip lightly. Time-aware updates: track score drift over time (slang like sick). Fit a simple state-space model per item to detect semantic shift. Explainability: log which anchors and rules contributed. Order constraints are explainable; neural bits backfill nuance. 9) “Change” vs. “increase/decrease/vary” Model “change” explicitly as direction = 0 (unknown/neutral) and stability = −? until context clarifies. increase/decrease set direction to ±1. vary/fluctuate set stability negative (volatile) and direction near 0 unless a trend is stated. Terms like delta and variance map to numeric magnitude and dispersion axes; these are useful features for analytical text. 10) Minimal viable build order Seeded lexicon + embeddings expansion + isotonic ordering for type scores. Dependency-based negation + intensifier rules. Token-level sense disambiguation with a small transformer. Optional: sarcasm flagger + domain adapters. Multilingual: start with MT projection, then add bilingual alignment and graph propagation. If you want, I can sketch a tiny Python prototype spec next—just enough to score words on a couple of scales, apply negation/intensifiers in context, and spit out reasons. From there, we’d plug in sense disambiguation and then scale up to multilingual with propagation. ChatGPT said: Thought for 7s Here’s a compact, buildable Python prototype spec you can paste into a repo and grow. It’s intentionally small but end-to-end: seed lexicon → (optional) embedding expansion → isotonic ordering of type scores → dependency-based negation/intensifiers → token-level scoring with sense buckets (stubbed) → hooks for sarcasm, domains, and multilingual. 0) Minimal project layout scales/ __init__.py seeds.py # tiny hand seeds + pairwise order constraints graph.py # synonym/antonym graph + label propagation isotonic.py # order-preserving calibration embeddings.py # neighbor expansion (gensim / sentence-transformers) typescores.py # builds type-level lexicon vectors context/ __init__.py parser.py # spaCy pipeline (tokenize, POS, deps) rules.py # negation/intensifiers/downtoners/direction senses.py # sense buckets via contextual embeddings (stub) sarcasm.py # sarcasm flagger (stub) domains.py # domain adapters (stub) scorer.py # token-level scorer + explanations api/ __init__.py service.py # FastAPI endpoints (/score_word, /score_token, /scale_between) demo.py # quick demo on a sentence requirements.txt requirements.txt (lean) spacy>=3.7 scikit-learn>=1.4 networkx>=3.2 numpy>=1.26 pandas>=2.2 gensim>=4.3 # optional: neighbor expansion with static embeddings sentence-transformers>=3.0 # small transformer for senses (stub) fastapi>=0.111 uvicorn>=0.30 1) Scales & seeds # scales/seeds.py from dataclasses import dataclass from typing import Dict, List, Tuple ScaleName = str @dataclass class ScaleConfig: name: ScaleName anchors_ordered: List[str] # weakest → strongest (or negative → positive) range_min: float = -1.0 range_max: float = 1.0 # Minimal example scales POLARITY = ScaleConfig( name="polarity", anchors_ordered=["terrible","bad","meh","okay","good","great","fantastic"], range_min=-1.0, range_max=1.0, ) INTENSITY = ScaleConfig( name="intensity", anchors_ordered=["faint","slight","moderate","strong","intense","extreme"], ) TEMPERATURE = ScaleConfig( name="temperature", anchors_ordered=["freezing","cold","cool","lukewarm","warm","hot","boiling"] ) DIRECTION = ScaleConfig( name="direction", anchors_ordered=["decrease","fall","drop","stable","rise","increase","surge"] ) STABILITY = ScaleConfig( name="stability", anchors_ordered=["volatile","choppy","variable","steady","stable"] ) # Pairwise constraints for isotonic (A < B on a scale) # Keep tiny; you can crowdsource more later. PAIRWISE: Dict[ScaleName, List[Tuple[str,str]]] = { "polarity": [("bad","okay"), ("okay","good"), ("good","great")], "intensity":[("slight","moderate"), ("moderate","strong"), ("strong","extreme")], "temperature":[("cool","warm"), ("warm","hot"), ("hot","boiling")], "direction":[("stable","rise"), ("rise","surge"), ("fall","decrease")], # loose "stability":[("volatile","steady"), ("steady","stable")], } # Seed multipliers for modifiers (empirical; tweak later) INTENSIFIERS = { "very": 1.4, "extremely": 1.8, "super": 1.6, "really": 1.2, "slightly": 0.7, "somewhat": 0.85, "barely": 0.5, "mildly": 0.8, } REVERSERS_LIMITERS = {"only":0.85, "just":0.9, "merely":0.85} NEGATORS = {"not","never","no","hardly","scarcely","barely"} # barely as neg-ish for polarity DIRECTION_LEMMAS = { "increase": +1.0, "rise": +0.8, "surge": +1.0, "climb": +0.7, "decrease": -1.0, "fall": -0.8, "drop": -0.8, "plunge": -1.0, "stabilize": 0.0, "stabilise": 0.0, "steady": 0.0, "fluctuate": 0.0, "vary": 0.0, } 2) Embedding expansion (optional but handy) # scales/embeddings.py from typing import List, Dict import numpy as np try: from gensim.models import KeyedVectors except Exception: KeyedVectors = None def load_kv(path:str) -> "KeyedVectors": if KeyedVectors is None: raise RuntimeError("gensim not installed") return KeyedVectors.load(path, mmap='r') if path.endswith(".kv") else KeyedVectors.load_word2vec_format(path, binary=True) def neighbors(kv, anchors:List[str], topn:int=20) -> Dict[str, float]: """Return candidate terms near anchors; score = mean cosine to anchors present in kv.""" cands: Dict[str, List[float]] = {} present = [a for a in anchors if a in kv] for a in present: for w, sim in kv.most_similar(a, topn=topn): cands.setdefault(w, []).append(sim) return {w: float(np.mean(sims)) for w,sims in cands.items() if w not in anchors} 3) Syn/ant graph + label propagation (tiny) # scales/graph.py import networkx as nx from typing import Dict, Iterable, Tuple def build_graph(syn_edges:Iterable[Tuple[str,str]], ant_edges:Iterable[Tuple[str,str]]) -> nx.Graph: G = nx.Graph() for a,b in syn_edges: G.add_edge(a,b,weight=+1.0) for a,b in ant_edges: G.add_edge(a,b,weight=-1.0) return G def propagate(G:nx.Graph, seeds:Dict[str,float], steps:int=2, alpha:float=0.8) -> Dict[str,float]: """Very small signed propagation: push seed values over +1 edges, invert over −1.""" scores = {n:0.0 for n in G.nodes} scores.update(seeds) for _ in range(steps): new = scores.copy() for u in G.nodes: accum, deg = 0.0, 0 for v in G.neighbors(u): w = G[u][v]['weight'] accum += (scores[v] * (1 if w>0 else -1)) deg += 1 if deg: new[u] = alpha*(accum/deg) + (1-alpha)*scores.get(u,0.0) scores = new return scores (Feed syn_edges/ant_edges from WordNet, ConceptNet, or your handcrafted mini-lists to start.) 4) Isotonic ordering (turn noisy real values into a clean, ordered scale) # scales/isotonic.py import numpy as np from sklearn.isotonic import IsotonicRegression from typing import Dict, List, Tuple def fit_isotonic(items:List[str], init_scores:Dict[str,float], pairwise:List[Tuple[str,str]], y_min=-1.0, y_max=1.0) -> Dict[str,float]: """ Convert pairwise (a<b) into a pseudo-x axis, solve a monotone fit from init_scores → y. Trick: we learn a monotone mapping f over the initial scores to respect order. """ # x: initial scores; y_order: impose order by ranking constraints as soft targets xs, names = [], [] for w in items: xs.append(init_scores.get(w, 0.0)) names.append(w) xs = np.array(xs) # Build soft targets using ranks induced by pairwise constraints. # Quick heuristic: iterate to lift winners and drop losers. y = np.zeros_like(xs) wins = {w:0 for w in names} for a,b in pairwise: if a in wins: wins[a] -= 1 if b in wins: wins[b] += 1 ranked = sorted(wins.items(), key=lambda kv: kv[1]) order_positions = {w:i for i,(w,_) in enumerate(ranked)} y = np.array([order_positions[w] for w in names], dtype=float) if len(set(y))>1: y = (y - y.min()) / max(1e-9, (y.max()-y.min())) y = y_min + y*(y_max - y_min) else: y = np.clip(xs, y_min, y_max) iso = IsotonicRegression(y_min=y_min, y_max=y_max, increasing=True, out_of_bounds='clip') y_hat = iso.fit_transform(xs, y) return {w: float(v) for w,v in zip(names, y_hat)} 5) Type-level vectors (combine scales into a per-lemma vector) # scales/typescores.py from typing import Dict, List from .seeds import ScaleConfig, POLARITY, INTENSITY, TEMPERATURE, DIRECTION, STABILITY, PAIRWISE from .embeddings import neighbors from .isotonic import fit_isotonic def _seed_init_scores(cfg:ScaleConfig) -> Dict[str,float]: # linear ramp from min → max over anchors n = len(cfg.anchors_ordered) if n==1: return {cfg.anchors_ordered[0]: 0.0} return {w: cfg.range_min + i*(cfg.range_max-cfg.range_min)/(n-1) for i,w in enumerate(cfg.anchors_ordered)} def expand_and_order(cfg:ScaleConfig, kv=None, topn=20) -> Dict[str,float]: init = _seed_init_scores(cfg) items = list(init.keys()) # Optional neighbor expansion from embeddings if kv is not None: neigh = neighbors(kv, cfg.anchors_ordered, topn=topn) # inherit scores by weighted average toward nearest anchor score (simple & fast) for w, sim in neigh.items(): # crude projection: map sim in [0,1] → toward mid; keep for ordering stage init[w] = 0.0 + sim * (cfg.range_max - cfg.range_min) * 0.2 items.append(w) # Isotonic fit under pairwise constraints pairwise = PAIRWISE.get(cfg.name, []) final = fit_isotonic(items=list(set(items)), init_scores=init, pairwise=pairwise, y_min=cfg.range_min, y_max=cfg.range_max) return final def build_type_vectors(kv=None) -> Dict[str, Dict[str,float]]: # Merge per-scale into a vector: {lemma: {scale: score}} per_scale = {} for cfg in [POLARITY, INTENSITY, TEMPERATURE, DIRECTION, STABILITY]: per_scale[cfg.name] = expand_and_order(cfg, kv=kv) vocab = set().union(*[set(d.keys()) for d in per_scale.values()]) vectors: Dict[str, Dict[str,float]] = {} for w in vocab: vectors[w] = {scale: d.get(w, 0.0) for scale, d in per_scale.items()} return vectors 6) Context parser + rules # context/parser.py import spacy from functools import lru_cache @lru_cache(maxsize=1) def get_nlp(): # small English pipeline; can swap in domain models return spacy.load("en_core_web_sm") def parse(text:str): return get_nlp()(text) # context/rules.py from typing import Dict, List from ..scales.seeds import INTENSIFIERS, REVERSERS_LIMITERS, NEGATORS, DIRECTION_LEMMAS def in_negation_scope(token) -> bool: # Dependency-based: if a negation child exists or governing negator in subtree if any(child.dep_ == "neg" or child.lemma_ in NEGATORS for child in token.children): return True # scan up to head for negation head = token.head if head is not token and any(c.dep_=="neg" or c.lemma_ in NEGATORS for c in head.children): return True return False def intensifier_multiplier(token) -> float: mult = 1.0 for ch in token.children: if ch.dep_ in {"advmod","amod"}: mult *= INTENSIFIERS.get(ch.lemma_.lower(), 1.0) if ch.lemma_.lower() in REVERSERS_LIMITERS: mult *= REVERSERS_LIMITERS[ch.lemma_.lower()] return mult def direction_override(token) -> float | None: # If the lemma is a change verb, return direction prior val = DIRECTION_LEMMAS.get(token.lemma_.lower()) return val 7) Sense buckets (stub you can swap later with Sentence-BERT) # context/senses.py from typing import Dict class SenseRouter: def __init__(self): # TODO: load a small sentence-transformers model; cluster by lemma; map to type scores self.enabled = False def sense_weight(self, lemma:str, context_text:str) -> Dict[str,float]: """ Returns per-sense mixture weights, e.g. {"physical":0.7,"figurative":0.3}. Prototype returns uniform → effectively “single sense”. """ return {"default": 1.0} 8) Sarcasm & domains (stubs) # context/sarcasm.py def sarcasm_factor(doc) -> float: # TODO: train a tiny classifier; until then return 1.0 (no change) or 0.7 if obvious clash patterns # Example heuristic: positive adjective + negative event noun return 1.0 # context/domains.py def domain_bias(domain:str, lemma:str) -> float: # domain-specific shifts: positive=+ε, negative=−ε return 0.0 9) Token-level scorer with explanations # context/scorer.py from typing import Dict, Any from ..scales.typescores import build_type_vectors from .parser import parse from .rules import in_negation_scope, intensifier_multiplier, direction_override from .senses import SenseRouter from .sarcasm import sarcasm_factor from .domains import domain_bias class TokenScorer: def __init__(self, kv=None, domain:str|None=None): self.type_vectors = build_type_vectors(kv=kv) # lemma → {scale→score} self.sense = SenseRouter() self.domain = domain or "general" def _type_vec(self, lemma:str) -> Dict[str,float]: return self.type_vectors.get(lemma, {"polarity":0.0,"intensity":0.0,"temperature":0.0,"direction":0.0,"stability":0.0}) def score_sentence(self, text:str) -> Dict[str, Any]: doc = parse(text) sark = sarcasm_factor(doc) results = [] for tok in doc: lem = tok.lemma_.lower() vec = self._type_vec(lem).copy() if not any(abs(v)>0 for v in vec.values()): continue # skip boring tokens reasons = [] mult = intensifier_multiplier(tok) if mult != 1.0: reasons.append(f"intensifier×{mult:.2f}") vec["intensity"] *= mult vec["temperature"] *= mult vec["polarity"] *= (1 + (mult-1)*0.5) # polarity responds but softer if in_negation_scope(tok): reasons.append("negation") vec["polarity"] *= -0.8 # invert & damp vec["intensity"] *= 0.8 d = direction_override(tok) if d is not None: reasons.append("direction verb") vec["direction"] = d # fluctuate/vary imply instability if lem in {"fluctuate","vary"}: vec["stability"] = -0.6 if lem in {"stabilize","steady"}: vec["stability"] = +0.6 # domain tweak dom = domain_bias(self.domain, lem) if dom != 0.0: reasons.append(f"domain_bias={dom:+.2f}") vec["polarity"] += dom # sarcasm attenuation if sark != 1.0: reasons.append("sarcasm") for k in ["polarity","intensity"]: vec[k] *= sark # confidence (toy): more rules fired → slightly lower confidence conf = max(0.4, 1.0 - 0.1*len(reasons)) results.append({ "token": tok.text, "lemma": lem, "scales": vec, "reasons": reasons or ["type_prior"], "confidence": conf }) return {"text": text, "tokens": results} 10) FastAPI surface (so you can poke it) # api/service.py from fastapi import FastAPI from pydantic import BaseModel from typing import Dict, Any from ..context.scorer import TokenScorer app = FastAPI(title="ScaleScorer") SCORER = TokenScorer(kv=None) # load embeddings if you want expansion class WordRequest(BaseModel): word: str class TokenRequest(BaseModel): text: str @app.post("/score_word") def score_word(req: WordRequest) -> Dict[str,Any]: vec = SCORER._type_vec(req.word.lower()) return {"word": req.word, "type_vector": vec} @app.post("/score_token") def score_token(req: TokenRequest) -> Dict[str,Any]: return SCORER.score_sentence(req.text) @app.get("/healthz") def health(): return {"ok": True} demo.py from api.service import SCORER s = 'The water is barely warm, but the price keeps rising.' res = SCORER.score_sentence(s) for t in res["tokens"]: if t["lemma"] in {"warm","rise","rising"}: print(t) Run the API: uvicorn api.service:app --reload How this maps to your 10-step plan Seeded lexicon + embeddings + isotonic → scales/* modules produce ordered type scores per scale. Negation + intensifiers → context/rules.py and used in scorer.py. Sense disambiguation → context/senses.py stub; later drop in a sentence-transformer to weight sense buckets per lemma. Sarcasm + domain adapters → stubs in sarcasm.py and domains.py, already wired to modulate scores. Multilingual → add language-specific spaCy pipelines, MT-projected seeds, bilingual embeddings, and a bilingual graph; keep isotonic calibration per language. The surface stays the same. Next increments (surgical, high-leverage) Sense router: cache a small all-MiniLM-L6-v2 model; collect contextual embeddings per lemma; KMeans into 2–4 senses; store sense→type-vector deltas; route by max cosine. Signed graph: pull syn/ant pairs from WordNet/ConceptNet and propagate before isotonic. Better confidence: combine rule count, OOV status, and sense entropy. Multilingual: project seeds via MT, then refine via MUSE/LaBSE bilingual space; run graph.propagate on a merged graph and recalibrate with a tiny per-language isotonic. This skeleton gives you a working path from “word on a scale” to “token in context with reasons,” while keeping every moving part small and swappable.
